title: 113_hr4855
content: Exception from passive loss rules for investments in high technology research small business pass-thru entities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude qualified research activities of a taxpayer carried out by a high technology research small business pass-thru entity from being considered passive activities. Losses or deductions related to these activities are not treated as such. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude losses and deductions from a passive activity for a taxpayer's high technology small business pass-thru entity, limited to the taxpayer's adjusted basis in the entity for qualified research activities. The taxpayer's basis for ownership interest in a partnership shall not include any portion attributable to an increase in liabilities considered as a money contribution. Carryovers of losses or deductions are not applicable to this provision. The provision excludes carryovers of losses or deductions into a different taxable year. Qualified research activity involves experimentation, and a high technology research small business pass-thru entity is defined as a domestic pass-thru entity meeting specific criteria. In a taxable year, if more than 75 percent of an entity's expenditures are for qualified research involving experimentation, or more than 50 percent of expenditures are for such research, it may qualify for certain benefits. In a taxable year, an entity may qualify for certain benefits if its expenditures for qualified research expenses meet specific criteria, it is a small business with aggregate gross assets not exceeding $150,000,000. The term 'aggregate gross assets' is defined in section 1202(d)(2). Section 197 intangibles used directly in research are excluded from the calculation of aggregate gross assets. Cash from equity sales for follow-on investments is also exempt. Investments - Cash from equity sales is excluded from calculating aggregate gross assets if the entity's assets do not exceed $150,000,000 plus 25% of assets before the sale. Sales of equity interests are subject to a limit of $150,000,000, with inflation adjustments applicable after 2015. Transactions involving equity interests as part of the same plan or for the purpose of increasing cash are treated as a single sale. The limit for sales of equity interests is $150,000,000, with inflation adjustments applied after 2015. The amount in subparagraph (E)(iii) and subclauses (I) and (II) of clause (iii) will each increase by an amount determined by multiplying the dollar amount by the cost of living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. Any increase will be rounded to the nearest $100,000. The limit for sales of equity interests is $150,000,000, with inflation adjustments applied after 2015. Expenditures for the expenditures test shall not fail to be taken into account merely because they are chargeable to capital account. A pass-thru entity includes partnerships, S corporations, or other entities identified by the Secretary. Aggregation rules apply to all persons treated as a single employer under specific sections. The high technology research small business pass-thru entity is treated as a single entity for certain purposes. To qualify as such, the entity must meet the criteria with and without certain conditions. Additionally, certain rules regarding activities not engaged in for profit and economic substance do not apply to disallow the losses, deductions, and credits of the entity. Certain research-related deductions and credits of high technology research small business pass-thru entities are allowed for purposes of determining alternative minimum tax. This includes an exception for these entities in the case of a high technology research small business pass-thru entity. The paragraph discusses the allowance of research-related deductions and credits for high technology research small business pass-thru entities in determining alternative minimum tax. An exception is made for these entities in the case of a high technology research small business pass-thru entity. The amendments allow high technology research small business pass-thru entities to claim research credits without limitations. Effective for taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
